review_title: Better than other universities of this caliber
job_title: Graduate Admissions Counselor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The new company that does the food for the dining hall is doing a great job. Employees get a discounted meal plan. The education provided at the school is excellent, making it easy to be convincing when doing outreach, especially for healthcare grad programs. Job prospects for graduates are also particularly excellent. I feel good promoting them. As a private university, the pay is very slightly higher than UPitt and other schools in the area in terms of admissions work. CMU still pays more.
cons: Higher education is such a poorly paid field. At least Chatham isn't a public university, but nonetheless, this job pays enough to survive in Pittsburgh but not enough to thrive, making it hard to find the motivation to go the extra mile in the role. You can get a graduate degree reimbursed if you work here, but you can't do the degrees with worthwhile ROI, like healthcare. You're pretty much limited to MBA and humanities. You also have to work in the same position for the same pay for two years after you graduate. So, they pretty much make getting more education, at least at the graduate level, not really make sense. They make you pay for a parking pass. This feels so greedy to me, considering what administrators in higher ed are paid.

review_title: No support, no training, many responsibilities
job_title: Library Reference Associate  in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The students and university faculty are wonderful.
cons: Library staff do not train, there is no support from other staff while you are working. From your first shift you will almost always be the only library staff member in the building, and you will be told not to ask for help, regardless of the scale of a problem. Your reference will emphasize that even though you are the person handling all contact with students, faculty, and the broader community (this is far more than ready reference), the institution in no way considers you any sort of librarian. Basically your reference will make it sound like this is a low level internship. If you are looking for a position in the region, there is a good chance that another library will be aware of how much you really do here, but libraries elsewhere the reference will have no idea that the bland lousy references they receive do not reflect your real responsibilities or the skills you have displayed and developed. Frankly, you'd be better off working at a coffee shop while finding local short term internships, paid or even unpaid, to develop references and your resume.

pros: Excellent, compassionate faculty focused on student performance and outcomes. Faculty were almost uniformly collegial and and committed to student excellence. cons: Turnover is an excellent indicator of terrible leadership and that holds true at Chatham. The president is an excellent crisis manager but this requires constant crises to shine.
